items.passage: Samuel Coleridge-Taylor was a prominent classical music composer from England who toured the US three times in the early 1900s. The child of a West African father and an English mother, Coleridge-Taylor emphasized his mixed‐race ancestry. For example, he referred to himself as Anglo-African. ______blank he incorporated the sounds of traditional African music into his classical music compositions.
items.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?
items.rationale: Choice A is the best answer because 'In addition,' logically signals that the detail—that Coleridge-Taylor incorporated traditional African sounds into his work—adds to the information already provided about his mixed-race identity.

items.passage: In her poetry collection Thomas and Beulah, Rita Dove interweaves the titular characters’ personal stories with broader historical narratives. She places Thomas’s journey from the American South to the Midwest in the early 1900s within the larger context of the Great Migration. ______blank Dove sets events from Beulah’s personal life against the backdrop of the US Civil Rights Movement.
items.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?
items.rationale: Choice D is the best answer because 'Similarly,' signals that, just as Thomas’s experiences are placed in a larger historical context, Beulah’s personal events are also set against a significant historical backdrop.

items.passage: In a heated debate in biogeography, the field is divided between dispersalists and vicariancists. ______blank there are those who argue that dispersal is the most crucial determining factor in a species’ distribution, and those who insist that vicariance (separation due to geographic barriers) is. Biogeographer Isabel Sanmartín counts herself among neither.
items.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?
items.rationale: Choice D is the best answer because 'That is,' introduces a clarification, explaining the two competing views (dispersal vs. vicariance) that define the debate in biogeography.

items.passage: Most of the planets that have been discovered outside our solar system orbit G-type stars, like our Sun. In 2014, ______blank researchers identified a planet orbiting KELT-9, a B-type star more than twice as massive and nearly twice as hot as the Sun. Called KELT-9b, it is one of the hottest planets ever discovered.
items.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?
items.rationale: Choice B is the best answer because 'however,' signals a contrast. While most planets orbit Sun-like stars, this discovery shows a planet orbiting a much hotter, more massive star.

items.passage: In 1815, while in exile in Jamaica, Venezuelan revolutionary Simón Bolívar penned a letter praising England’s republican government and expressing hope that Latin American nations seeking independence from Spain might achieve something similar. The letter was addressed to a local merchant, Henry Cullen; ______blank though, Bolívar’s goal was to persuade political leaders from England and Europe to support his cause.
items.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?
items.rationale: Choice B is the best answer because 'ultimately,' indicates that despite the letter being addressed to a merchant, Bolívar’s final aim was to reach higher-level political figures.

items.passage: The Babylonian king Hammurabi achieved much during his forty-year reign. He conquered all of Mesopotamia and built Babylon into one of the most powerful cities of the ancient world. Today, ______blank he is mainly remembered for a code of laws inscribed on a seven-foot-tall block of stone: the Code of Hammurabi.
items.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?
items.rationale: Choice C is the best answer because 'however,' signals a contrast: despite his many achievements, Hammurabi is now primarily remembered for one specific contribution.

items.passage: Some members of the US Supreme Court have resisted calls to televise the court’s oral arguments, concerned that the participants would be tempted to perform for the cameras (and thus lower the quality of the discourse). ______blank the justices worry that most viewers would not even watch the full deliberations, only short clips that could be misinterpreted and mischaracterized.
items.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?
items.rationale: Choice B is the best answer because 'Additionally,' indicates that this sentence adds another concern held by the justices regarding televising oral arguments.

items.passage: Award-winning travel writer Linda Watanabe McFerrin considers the background research she conducts on destinations featured in her travel books to be its own reward. ______blank McFerrin admits to finding the research phase of her work just as fascinating and engaging as exploring a location in person.
items.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?
items.rationale: Choice D is the best answer because 'In fact,' emphasizes and elaborates on McFerrin's claim, reinforcing that the research phase is as rewarding as the experience of travel.

items.passage: In 1873, Spanish scientist Santiago Ramón y Cajal observed that brain fibers have distinct boundaries with clear end points, a finding that went against earlier assumptions about the brain. ______blank scientists had assumed that the brain was a continuous web of fused fibers, not a vast network of distinct, individual cells.
items.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?
items.rationale: Choice B is the best answer because 'Previously,' indicates that before Ramón y Cajal’s observations, scientists held a different, now disproven view of the brain’s structure.

items.passage: For years, biologists have experimented with using grime-eating bacteria rather than harsh chemicals to clean artworks, and results have been impressive overall. ______blank these bacterial strains—which can metabolize centuries’ worth of oil, glue, dirt, and other surface impurities without creating harmful byproducts—have proven more effective than traditional chemical cleaning methods.
items.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?
items.rationale: Choice B is the best answer because 'In many cases,' implies that in numerous experiments, the bacterial cleaning methods have been effective, supporting the claim of impressive results.

items.passage: In 1968, US Congressman John Conyers introduced a bill to establish a national holiday in honor of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. The bill didn’t make it to a vote, but Conyers was determined. He teamed up with Shirley Chisholm, the first Black woman to be elected to Congress, and they resubmitted the bill every session for the next fifteen years. ______blank in 1983, the bill passed.
items.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?
items.rationale: Choice C is the best answer because 'Finally,' signals that after many years of repeated efforts, the desired outcome was ultimately achieved in 1983.

items.passage: It has long been thought that humans first crossed a land bridge into the Americas approximately 13,000 years ago. ______blank based on radiocarbon dating of samples uncovered in Mexico, a research team recently suggested that humans may have arrived more than 30,000 years ago—much earlier than previously thought.
items.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?
items.rationale: Choice C is the best answer because 'However,' signals a contrast between the previously held theory and the new findings based on radiocarbon dating.

items.passage: Researchers believe that pieces of hull found off Oregon’s coast are from a Spanish cargo ship that was lost in 1697. Stories passed down among the area’s Confederated Tribes of Siletz Indians support this belief. ______blank Siletz stories describe how blocks of beeswax, an item the ship had been carrying, began washing ashore after the ship was lost.
items.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?
items.rationale: Choice B is the best answer because 'For example,' introduces a specific instance—the beeswax stories—that supports the earlier claim regarding the shipwreck.

items.passage: Alexander Lawrence Posey (1873–1908) varied his focus and tone depending on the genre in which he was writing. In his poetry, he used heartfelt language to evoke the beauty and peacefulness of his natural surroundings; in his journalism, ______blank he employed humor and satire to comment on political issues affecting his Muskogee Creek community.
items.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?
items.rationale: Choice D is the best answer because 'by contrast,' signals a clear difference between the tone of his poetry and the tone of his journalism.

items.passage: Geoscientists have long considered Hawaii’s Mauna Loa volcano to be Earth’s largest shield volcano by volume, measuring approximately 74,000 cubic kilometers. ______blank according to a 2020 study by local geoscientist Michael Garcia, Hawaii’s Pūhāhonu shield volcano is significantly larger, boasting a volume of about 148,000 cubic kilometers.
items.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?
items.rationale: Choice D is the best answer because 'However,' signals a contrast between the long-held belief about Mauna Loa and the new findings that suggest a different volcano is larger.

items.passage: The parasitic dodder plant increases its reproductive success by flowering at the same time as the host plant it has latched onto. In 2020, Jianqiang Wu and his colleagues determined that the tiny dodder achieves this ______blank with its host by absorbing and utilizing a protein the host produces when it is about to flower.
items.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?
items.rationale: Choice A is the best answer because, in this context, 'synchronization' refers to the process of matching the timing of flowering between the dodder and its host. By absorbing a protein produced by the host before it flowers, the dodder is able to flower at the same time.

items.passage: Sumerian civilization (which lasted from around 3300 to 2000 BCE) ______blank many concepts that persist into present-day civilizations: for example, the first description of the seven-day week appears in the Sumerian Epic of Gilgamesh.
items.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?
items.rationale: Choice B is the best answer because 'introduced' means to bring into use for the first time. The Sumerians provided the earliest recorded example of many concepts, such as the seven-day week, that continue to influence modern societies.

items.passage: Physicist Joseph Weber performed ______blank work in gravitational wave research in the 1960s and 1970s, conducting key experiments that scientists later used as the basis for their own investigations that led to the first verified detection of a gravitational wave in 2015.
items.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?
items.rationale: Choice A is the best answer because 'foundational' means serving as a base on which future work is built. Weber’s experiments laid the groundwork that later led to the detection of gravitational waves.

items.passage: As an architect in Los Angeles in the 1950s, Helen Liu Fong became known for avoiding ______blank designs in her buildings. Instead of using standard shapes and colors, she typically explored innovative forms and daring hues.
items.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?
items.rationale: Choice C is the best answer because 'traditional' refers to conventional or standard designs. Fong distinguished herself by rejecting conventional (traditional) forms in favor of innovative approaches.

items.passage: US traffic signals didn’t always contain the familiar three lights (red, yellow, and green). Traffic lights only ______blank red and green lights until the three-light traffic signal was developed in the 1920s.
items.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?
items.rationale: Choice B is the best answer because 'featured' means that red and green lights were the standard components of traffic signals before the addition of a yellow light.

items.passage: Given that the conditions in binary star systems should make planetary formation nearly impossible, it’s not surprising that the existence of planets in such systems has lacked ______blank explanation. Roman Rafikov and Kedron Silsbee shed light on the subject when they used modeling to determine a complex set of factors that could support planets’ development.
items.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?
items.rationale: Choice B is the best answer because 'a straightforward explanation' implies that a simple, clear explanation is lacking, which is why complex modeling is needed to understand planet formation in binary star systems.

items.passage: Award-winning travel writer Linda Watanabe McFerrin considers the background research she conducts on destinations featured in her travel books to be its own reward. ______blank McFerrin admits to finding the research phase of her work just as fascinating and engaging as exploring a location in person.
items.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?
items.rationale: Choice B is the best answer because 'In fact,' emphasizes and reinforces McFerrin's claim that the research phase is as rewarding as direct exploration.

items.passage: The recent discovery of a carved wooden figure dating to around 2,000 years ago in a ditch in England was truly surprising. Wooden objects ______blank survive for so long due to their high susceptibility to rot, but archaeologists suspect layers of sediment in the ditch preserved the figure by creating an oxygen-free environment.
items.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?
items.rationale: Choice C is the best answer because 'rarely' conveys that it is uncommon for wooden objects to survive for such long periods due to their tendency to rot, making the discovery notable.

items.passage: According to statistician Nassim Nicholas Taleb, the best way to predict the amount of time a nonperishable entity (such as a building or a technology) will continue to exist is to examine how long it has survived so far. In this view, an item’s age is the strongest ______blank how much longer it will last.
items.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?
items.rationale: Choice B is the best answer because 'indicator' means something that shows or suggests a condition. Here, an item’s age serves as an indicator of its potential longevity.

items.passage: In 1873, Spanish scientist Santiago Ramón y Cajal observed that brain fibers have distinct boundaries with clear end points, a finding that went against earlier assumptions about the brain. ______blank scientists had assumed that the brain was a continuous web of fused fibers, not a vast network of distinct, individual cells.
items.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?
items.rationale: Choice B is the best answer because 'Previously,' indicates that the earlier belief (that the brain was a continuous web) existed before Ramón y Cajal’s discovery, setting up the contrast between past assumptions and his findings.

items.passage: Okot p’Bitek’s poem Song of Lawino (1966) explores postcolonial Ugandan life through the eyes of a woman living in a rural village. With its vibrant imagery, bitingly satiric tone, and dexterous use of traditional Acholi song and phraseology, the poem inspired a generation of East African writers. ______blank those who adopted its style are often referred to as Okot School poets.
items.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?
items.rationale: Choice B is the best answer. 'Fittingly' means appropriately or suitably, and it indicates that writers who adopted Okot p’Bitek’s style were appropriately called the Okot School poets.

items.passage: Before the 1847 introduction of the US postage stamp, the cost of postage was usually paid by the recipient of a letter rather than the sender, and recipients were not always able or willing to pay promptly. ______blank collecting this fee could be slow and arduous, and heaps of unpaid-for, undeliverable mail piled up in post offices.
items.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?
items.rationale: Choice C is the best answer. 'Consequently' signals that the difficulties in collecting the fee led to slow, arduous processes and piles of undeliverable mail.

items.passage: A potter choosing which type of clay to use for a piece considers two key factors: the desired look of the piece and its intended use. ______blank earthenware clay is often used for decorative pieces because of its rustic look. This type of clay is not often used in industrial settings, though, because it is less durable than other clays.
items.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?
items.rationale: Choice D is the best answer. 'For example,' indicates that the sentence that follows provides an illustration—earthenware clay being used for decorative purposes.

items.passage: In Gothic architecture, flying buttresses are large arches that help support a building’s exterior walls. Before the Gothic era, cathedrals’ heavy ceilings had to be supported by thick, short walls, but the invention of flying buttresses eliminated this need. ______blank Gothic cathedrals could be built with thinner, higher walls.
items.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?
items.rationale: Choice D is the best answer. 'As a result,' indicates that because of flying buttresses, the structural support requirements changed, allowing for thinner, higher walls.

items.passage: Tyrian purple was a highly prized dye among the Phoenicians (an ancient civilization located in present-day Lebanon). The Phoenicians were famous for using this natural dye to color their clothes a distinctive purple. ______blank the name 'Phoenicia' itself, some historians claim, may have originally meant 'land of purple.'
items.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?
items.rationale: Choice A is the best answer. 'In fact,' signals that the detail about the possible meaning of 'Phoenicia' reinforces the earlier claim about the prominence of purple dye in Phoenician culture.

items.passage: Etched into Peru’s Nazca Desert are line drawings so large that they can only be fully seen from high above. Archaeologists have known of the lines since the 1920s, when a researcher spotted some from a nearby foothill, and they have been studying the markings ever since. ______blank archaeologists’ efforts are aided by drones that capture high-resolution aerial photographs of the lines.
items.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?
items.rationale: Choice A is the best answer. 'Currently,' emphasizes that the use of drone technology is a present-day method aiding ongoing archaeological research in the Nazca Desert.

items.passage: Because an achiral molecule is symmetrical, flipping it yields a structurally identical molecule. A flipped chiral molecule, ______blank can be compared to a glove that has been turned inside out: it produces a structurally inverted molecule rather than an identical one.
items.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?
items.rationale: Choice B is the best answer. 'By contrast,' signals a difference: while achiral molecules yield identical structures when flipped, chiral molecules do not, much like turning a glove inside out.

items.passage: Most conifers (trees belonging to the phylum Coniferophyta) are evergreen. That is, they keep their green leaves or needles year-round. However, not all conifer species are evergreen. Larch trees, ______blank lose their needles every fall.
items.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?
items.rationale: Choice A is the best answer. 'For instance,' introduces larch trees as an example of a conifer species that does not retain its needles year-round.

items.passage: Jhumpa Lahiri’s story collection Interpreter of Maladies features multiple stories about romantic relationships. In 'This Blessed House,' newlyweds argue over whether to replace items left by the previous owners of their new home. ______blank in 'A Temporary Matter,' a husband and wife attempt to rekindle their relationship during a four-night blackout.
items.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?
items.rationale: Choice C is the best answer. 'Likewise,' signals that the scenario in 'A Temporary Matter' is similar in context to the argument in 'This Blessed House,' both exploring aspects of interpersonal relationships.

items.passage: Small, flat structures called spatulae are found at the tips of the hairs on a spider’s leg. These spatulae temporarily bond with the atoms of whatever they touch. ______blank spiders are able to cling to and climb almost any surface.
items.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?
items.rationale: Choice D is the best answer. 'As a result,' indicates that the bonding properties of the spatulae enable spiders to effectively cling to various surfaces.

items.passage: As a young historian in the 1950s, Alixa Naff began interviewing fellow Arab American immigrants about their experiences straddling two cultures. Over the next few decades, Naff conducted more than 450 such interviews, also known as oral histories. ______blank she collected photographs and other artifacts that represented her subjects’ experiences.
items.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?
items.rationale: Choice C is the best answer. 'In addition,' signals that besides conducting interviews, Naff also gathered additional artifacts to complement her research.

items.passage: Before California’s 1911 election to approve a proposition granting women the right to vote, activists across the state sold tea to promote the cause of suffrage. In San Francisco, the Woman’s Suffrage Party sold Equality Tea at local fairs. ______blank in Los Angeles, activist Nancy Tuttle Craig, who ran one of California’s largest grocery store firms, distributed Votes for Women Tea.
items.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?
items.rationale: Choice C is the best answer. 'Similarly,' indicates that the tea-selling activity in Los Angeles paralleled the one in San Francisco, thereby supporting the idea that activists nationwide used tea to promote suffrage.

items.passage: In 2019, researcher Patricia Jurado Gonzalez and food historian Nawal Nasrallah prepared a stew from a 4,000-year-old recipe found on a Mesopotamian clay tablet. When they tasted the dish, known as pašrūtum (“unwinding”), they found that it had a mild taste and inspired a sense of calm. ______blank the researchers, knowing that dishes were sometimes named after their intended effects, theorized that the dish’s name, 'unwinding,' referred to its function: to help ancient diners relax.
items.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?
items.rationale: Choice A is the best answer. 'Therefore,' signals that the researchers’ theory about the dish's name is a logical conclusion drawn from the observation that the dish had a calming effect.

items.passage: Neuroscientist Karen Konkoly wanted to determine whether individuals can understand and respond to questions during REM sleep. She first taught volunteers eye movements they would use to respond to basic math problems while asleep (a single left-right eye movement indicated the number one). ______blank she attached electrodes to the volunteers’ faces to record their eye movements during sleep.
items.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?
items.rationale: Choice B is the best answer. 'Next,' clearly indicates that the action of attaching electrodes follows as the subsequent step in Konkoly's experiment.

items.passage: In June, female loggerhead sea turtles will swim back to the sandy beaches where they were born to lay eggs of their own. First, the turtle will dig her nest in the sand. ______blank she will lay up to 100 eggs in the nest. Finally, she will cover it all with sand, before returning to the ocean.
items.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?
items.rationale: Choice C is the best answer. 'Next,' indicates that the egg-laying step follows nest digging in the sequence of events described.
